discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
TS - traffic selector - which traffic to be tunneled. TS_UNACCEPTABLE means the interesting traffic doesn't match

Selected Answer: A
While "C. Correct crypto access list on both VPN devices" is a possibility, it's less likely to be the root cause based on the error message "There was no IPSEC policy found for received TS." This error indicates a mismatch in the IPsec policy, not the access list.
I think A .. Why should we correct on BOTH devices the ACL? Makes no sense

the error message says, "There was no IPSEC POLICY found for received TS"
TS = Traffic selector (IP),
so this means nothing to do with the IP but rather IPSec policy

Selected Answer: A
Provided answer seems to be correct.
'A', seems to be the correct answer here.

Selected Answer: D
Traffic Selector mismatch, check the ACL for the interesting traffic on both nodes

Selected Answer: C
C - need to modify ACLs

Selected Answer: C
C - need to modify ACLs to properly identify interesting traffic

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. An IKEv2 site-to-site tunnel between an ASA and a remote peer is not building successfully. What will fix the problem based on the debug output?

choices.D: Specify the peer IP address in the tunnel group name.
choices.B: Install the correct certificate to validate the peer.
choices.C: Correct crypto access list on both VPN devices.
choices.A: Ensure crypto IPsec policy matches on both VPN devices.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
I think A and D
since B is supported later

Note: ASA version 7.2.x supports two methods: group-url and group-alias list.
Note: ASA version 8.0.x supports three methods: group-url, group-alias, and certificate-maps.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/security/asa-5500-x-series-next-generation-firewalls/98580-enable-group-dropdown.html

Selected Answer: BD
The Alias help to map, that is correct, however, the questions say that you are not using the tunnel list feature, and that feature shows the Aliases of all the connection profiles, if you are not using that feature, there is no way you can see the Alias, therefore you cannot map to any VPN

Cert maps and Group URLs are the correct answer
B and D

To map a VPN session to a tunnel group without using the tunnel-group list, you can use the parameters certificate mapping and group-url. These parameters help in associating a VPN session with a specific tunnel group.

So, the correct combination is:

Certificate mapping
Group-url
Certificate mapping allows you to map user attributes to specific connection profiles based on information present in the user's certificate. The group-url is a parameter that allows users to connect to a specific group URL, which, in turn, is associated with a particular tunnel group.

Therefore, the correct answer is certificate mapping and group-url.

BD is correct

https://integratingit.wordpress.com/2022/03/23/asa-group-url-and-alias/

Selected Answer: AD
AD is correct

Selected Answer: BD
BD

A. group-alias --> This is a tunnel-group list on the logon page but the question asked not to use the tunnel-group list.

B. certificate map --> Can assign the user to a tunnel-group without the tunnel-group list.

C. optimal gateway selection --> Completely different feature.

D. group-url --> Can assign the user to a tunnel-group without the tunnel-group list.

E. AnyConnect client version --> Can be used in certain decisions in DAP but i don't think it can assign a tunnel group based on client version.

Selected Answer: AD
A and D
I think A and D are correct: https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/security/asa-5500-x-series-next-generation-firewalls/98580-enable-group-dropdown.html

questions.question_text: Which two parameters help to map a VPN session to a tunnel group without using the tunnel-group list? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B is correct
https://networksec-solutions.com/cisco-asa-ssl-clientless-vpn/

choices.C: Enable DTLS under the group policy.
choices.D: Enable auto sign-on for the user's IP address.
choices.B: Enable clientless protocol under the group policy.
choices.A: Enable client services on the outside interface.

Refer to the exhibit. A network engineer is reconfiguring clientless SSLVPN during a maintenance window, and after testing the new configuration, is unable to establish the connection. What must be done to remediate this problem?

The Key Server is responsible for authenticating GMs. The KS
manages security policies that determine which traffic should be encrypted.

Selected Answer: BE

questions.question_text: What are two purposes of the key server in Cisco IOS GETVPN? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
tunnelall - This keyword specifies that all traffic goes through the tunnel. Users can reach the Internet through the tunnel.
tunnelspecified -This keyword tunnels all traffic from or to the specified networks. This option enables split tunneling. It lets you create a network list of addresses to tunnel. Data to all other addresses travels in the clear, and is routed by the remote userâ€™s Internet service provider.
excludespecified - This keyword defines a list of networks to which traffic goes in the clear. This feature is useful for remote users who want to access devices on their local network, such as printers, while they are connected to the corporate network through a tunnel.

Correct answer is C, here is why:
Now, specify the split tunnel mode. You can choose from the following three options:

 excludespecified (exclude only networks specified by split-tunnel-network-list)
 tunnelall (tunnel everything)
 tunnelspecified (tunnel only networks specified by split-tunnel-network-list)

you're going to all all non RFC-1918 in ACL if you choose Answer D, the correct answer is C tunnel only whats included in ACL, the rest will go over ISP not tunnel. remember work smart!

Selected Answer: D
The split-tunneling policy that allows a remote client to use their local provider for internet access when working from home is usually called "excludespecified".
D is the correct answer

exclude specified is correct, notes from Cisco community: In an exclude-specified configuration; AnyConnect will not tunnel traffic to or from the networks specified in the Network List. Traffic from or to all other addresses is tunneled

questions.question_text: An engineer notices that while an employee is connected remotely, all traffic is being routed to the corporate network. Which split-tunnel policy allows a remote client to use their local provider for Internet access when working from home?
